Author: Junko Yoshida
Keywords: Automotive, Business Topics, Compilers & Linkers, Digital, Hardware Development, Industries, Microprocessor, Mission Critical, Patents & Licensing, Semiconductors, SoC, Software, Transportation
Article: TOKYOÂ â AI processor designer Blaize, formerly known as ThinCI (pronounced âThink-Eyeâ), revealed its fully programmable Graph Streaming Processor (GSP) will go into volume production in the second quarter of 2020. While the six-year-old startup is mum on its product specificationsÂ â such as power level and benchmarking results â its test chip, taped out in mid-2018 and housed in a Linux-based box, has been engaged in 16 pilot programs worldwide for a year, claimed Blaize co-founder and CEO Dinakar Munagala. Blaize describes its GSP as capable of performing âdirect graph processing, on-chip task-graph management and execution, and task parallelism.â In short, Blaize designed the GSP to fulfill AI processing needs that have been previously unmet by GPU, CPU or DSP. To many industry analysts covering AI processors, this is a pitch theyâve heard before. Kevin Krewell, principal analyst at Tirias Research, said, âI know a bit about ThinCI, but never got the architecture pitch. I'm glad they changed the name though.â The dearth of technical details on the GSP architecture in its slide presentation is feeding frustration and skepticism in the tech analyst community. Munagala, however, promises an information release in the first quarter of 2020.  High-level block diagram of the GSP architecture       (Source: Blaize)
